content.question:
A recent study reported the mean body mass index <math alttext="B M I" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">M</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">I</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> for adults in the United States was 26.8. A researcher believes the mean <math alttext="body mass index" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext><mtext>M</mtext><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of marathon runners is less than 26.8. A random sample of 35 marathon runners had a mean <math alttext="body mass index" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext><mtext>M</mtext><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> of 22.7 with a standard deviation of 3.1. The researcher will conduct a one-sample <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-test for a population mean.
Have the conditions for inference been met?

choices.label: Yes, all conditions have been met.
No, because the sample was not selected using a random method.
No, because marathon runners are not a representative sample of all adults in the United States.
No, because the shape of the distribution of the sample is not known.
No, because the sample size is not large enough to assume normality of the sampling distribution of the sample mean.

content.answer: Yes, all conditions have been met.

topic.text: 7.4: Setting Up a Test for a Population Mean
